title: How to Add Potassium to an Organic Garden

steps.title: Mix in muriate of potash or sulfate of potash.
steps.content: Mix in muriate of potash or sulfate of potash. Muriate of potash, or potassium chloride, and sulfate of potash, or potassium sulfate, are natural minerals. Muriate of potash tends to be cheaper, but the chlorine it contains can hurt the helpful microbes living in your garden's soil. Sulfate of potash is safer, but it’s a bit more expensive. [1] X Research source Check your product’s label for specific instructions on how much to add per square foot or meter. Make sure the product you purchase is certified organic by the Organic Minerals Review Institute (OMRI).

steps.title: Try kelp meal or seaweed.
steps.content: Try kelp meal or seaweed. Kelp and other types of seaweed are rich in potassium, and quickly release it into soil. You can either mix a few handfuls of dried kelp meal into the soil or by spray it with a liquid seaweed spray. [2] X Research source Mix in a pound of kelp meal per square foot of soil (about 450 grams for 9 square meters).

steps.title: Try Sul-Po-Mag.
steps.content: Try Sul-Po-Mag. Also called langbeinite or sulfate of potash-magnesia, Sul-Po-Mag is your most affordable option. It’s best to use it if a soil test reveals your soil is low in both potassium and magnesium. Check your product’s label to ensure it’s OMRI certified and for recommended amounts per square foot or meter.

steps.title: Add hardwood ash only if you need to increase the soil’s pH.
steps.content: Add hardwood ash only if you need to increase the soil’s pH. Sprinkle 1 to 2 pounds of ash per 100 square feet (450 to 900 grams per 9 square meters). [3] X Research source Wood ash raises soil pH, or decreases the acidity. If you use wood ash to supply the garden with potassium, it’s best to regularly test the pH to make sure that the soil is balanced. Don’t use wood ash around acid-loving plants, like azaleas or blueberries.

steps.title: Add greensand to your soil.
steps.content: Add greensand to your soil. Use about 5 pounds (2.25 kilograms) per 100 square feet (9 square meters) of soil. Greensand releases potassium at a slow rate, so it’s better for long-term soil maintenance than quick adjustments. It also works as a conditioner and helps soil retain water. [4] X Research source In addition to digging greensand into your soil directly, you can also add it to your compost pile to improve the potassium content of your compost.

steps.title: Add granite dust.
steps.content: Add granite dust. Granite dust is mined from natural granite quarries and is fairly inexpensive. Like greensand, it releases potassium slowly, so it won’t work well if you need to make a quick fix. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Bury banana peels in your soil.
steps.content: Bury banana peels in your soil. Cut up peels into small pieces and bury them an inch or two (4 or 5 centimeters) in your soil. The peels will take time to rot, so they’ll release potassium more slowly than other amendments. Adding banana peels directly to your soil will also help deter aphids. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Beef up your compost with banana peels.
steps.content: Beef up your compost with banana peels. To increase your compost's potassium content, add fruit and vegetable waste to the pile. Banana peels are your best bet, but orange rinds, lemon rinds, beets, spinach, and tomatoes will make excellent additions, too. [7] X Research source Keep in mind you’ll need to give your compost weeks or months to mature.

steps.title: Keep your compost covered to prevent potassium leaching.
steps.content: Keep your compost covered to prevent potassium leaching. Use a lidded container or cover your compost heap with a tarp when you’re not using it. Potassium compounds are water soluble, so rainfall can easily wash them out of your compost. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Have your soil tested every one to two years.
steps.content: Have your soil tested every one to two years. For most gardeners, it’s recommended to have your soil lab tested every two years. If you’re a serious gardener and want to maximize your crop, test your soil every season before you plant. The results will let you know if your soil contains low, medium, optimum, or high levels of potassium, nitrogen, phosphorus, and other nutrients. Search online for a nearby university or other soil-testing lab, or contact your local extension agent.

steps.title: Add potassium when your crop starts to flower and fruit.
steps.content: Add potassium when your crop starts to flower and fruit. If you’re growing fruits and vegetables, prevent potassium deficiency by giving your plants a potassium boost when they start to flower. When they flower and fruit, plants can deplete their potassium supply in a matter of days.

steps.title: Add potassium if you spot signs of deficiency.
steps.content: Add potassium if you spot signs of deficiency. Signs of deficiency include yellow leaves and brown leaf edges. Discoloration usually occurs in older leaves first, or those closer to the bottom of your plant. In fruiting plants, like tomatoes, you might see uneven ripening or yellow patches on the fruit.

steps.title: Monitor your plants more closely if you have sandy soil.
steps.content: Monitor your plants more closely if you have sandy soil. Because of its high solubility, potassium can easily leach out of soil, especially in coarse, sandy soils. Keep a close eye on your plants if you know leaching could be an issue. If possible, test your soil more frequently. Amending your sandy soil with manure and well-rotted compost can help prevent leaching.

steps.title: Check for signs of magnesium deficiency.
steps.content: Check for signs of magnesium deficiency. Adding more potassium can lower the amount of other nutrients that the plant absorbs. Potassium competes with magnesium most directly, so look for yellowing between leaves’ veins. The veins themselves stay green, but the spaces between them turn yellow. If you add potassium but notice yellowing occurs or worsens, just purchase an organic calcium-magnesium supplement or magnesium sulfate. Depending on your product, you’ll either mix it into the soil or spray it onto your plant’s bottom leaves.
